Posts.Content: Jan 3, 2012 04:32PM Lucille3361 wrote: Maxkolbe, I, too, live alone and I did fine with my chemo. My body needed to shut down and rest for two hours after work each day and I let it! Avoid getting sick by taking the anti nausea and vomiting meds BEFORE you get sick, on a regular schedule, and you will be good. Being single was hard when I had to lug out the garbage and clean cat litter :)  You can do it!!!
Posts.Title: January 2012 chemo ely Momof2inME

Posts.Content: Jan 3, 2012 04:27PM Lucille3361 wrote: Hi, I am new to this site. I just finished my chemo and I was able to work all through it without a sick day. I teach college, so it was a bit easier than a hard labor job. Just be sure to take your anti nausea and vomiting meds on a regular schedule BEFORE you even get sick. You can avoid it the entire time. The fatigue is great, but doable. I had the gene test on my tumor but to do that test you had to be ER+ and rest negative and I still had to have chemo to avoid recurrance. Starting radiation tomorrow. Good luck. Cindy
Posts.Title: January 2012 chemo ely Momof2inME

Posts.Content: Jan 3, 2012 04:43PM Lucille3361 wrote: Hello all, I went in for my routine mammogram and it showed abnormality. Last years mammogram read Negative. Well, they misread last year's mammogram. This year I had a lumpectomy, 2.8cm, no node involvement. Just finished with chemo and starting radiation tomorrow. Thank God it was caught early.
Posts.Title: Lump not detected by mammorgram SueJR SueJR

Posts.Content: Jan 3, 2012 07:50PM Lucille3361 wrote: chef127, Hi, I had an oncotype test and my score came back high (31) so the Dr. recommended chemo to avoid recurrance. I was disappointed since I only had a lumpectomy, no node involvement, but it was 2.8 cm. All in all, chemo was not fun but it was doable. Gool luck.

Posts.Content: Jan 5, 2012 07:41PM Lucille3361 wrote: Mary, I, too, teach and work was my sanity...it normalizes this whole ordeal. The students understand my situation and are so helpful.

Posts.Content: Jan 3, 2012 07:47PM Lucille3361 wrote: Bobbi, I understand your reluctance to do radiation. I start tomorrow and I am very reluctant. My oncologist told me a tiny portion of my right lung will "die" from radiation. I feel if I don't do the radiation I will wonder "what if I had..."  You are right, it is the status quo.
Posts.Title: January 2012 rads Kate60 edoyrest

Posts.Content: Jan 5, 2012 07:40PM Lucille3361 wrote: Hi Helen, Thanks for responding! I love the bacon frying analogy! Would be nice to have a bite of it while we are frying under RAD!  I agree we will do anything to keep the monster away... during chemo I tried really hard to visualize the poison killing the evil cancer cells, but I always came back to the worry of it also killing good cells. Same with radiation. I, too, heard the fatigue will hit around the fourth week of treatments. I had serious fatigue, bone/muscle/nerve aches with chemo so I guess I will be used to it. Walking seems to help so far. I am glad to have all of these posts so I don't feel alone.
Posts.Title: January 2012 rads Kate60 edoyrest
